### Introduction
The Asian citrus psyllid, *Diaphorina citri* (Kuwayama) (Hemiptera: Liviidae) is one of the greatest threats to the citrus industry, because it acts as the primary vector for *Candidatus* Liberibacter asiaticus (*Alphaproteobacteria*), the bacteria which causes Citrus Greening Disease or Huanglongbing (HLB) [@Bove2006]. No cultivars of citrus have been found to be fully resistant to HLB [@]. High levels of infection reduce tree productivity and eventually kill the host plant. The Dundee Biological Control Laboratory is primarily responsible for the rearing and release of *Tamarixia radiata*, a parasitoid wasp of *D. citri* nymphs [@Qureshi2014].


Citrus psyllids prefer *Murraya paniculata* [@Ikeda2008], and psyllids raised on *Murraya* have lower levels of HLB [@Walter2012; @Walter2012a]

### Results

Maybe you want to show off some of that fancy code you spent so much time on to make that figure, well you can do that too! Just use the `echo=TRUE` option in the r code chunk options, Figure \@ref(fig:myprettycode)!

```{r myprettycode, echo=FALSE,collapse=TRUE, fig.cap='Boxplots, so hot right now!', fig.height=3.5, out.width="80%"}
df <-
  read_csv("clean_tam_yield_datasheet.csv",
           col_types = c("ff?????fff?fD"))

df$month <- month(df$date)
df$year <- year(df$date)

ggplot(data = df, mapping = aes(plant, tam_ct)) +
  geom_boxplot()
```
